Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cell Salvage in Obstetrics

Trial_Design.evidence: 34 patients undergoing elective Caesarean section at the Royal Cornwall Hospital were alternately assigned

Participants.evidence: 34 patients undergoing elective Caesarean section at the Royal Cornwall Hospital

Intervention.evidence: comparing one versus two suction devices

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate amniotic fluid (AF), heparin, and fetal red cell contamination

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction of AF, heparin, and fetal red cells post-filtration

Number_Randomised.evidence: 34 patients undergoing elective Caesarean section at the Royal Cornwall Hospital were alternately assigned to Group 1 (n=17, one suction) or Group 2 (n=17, two suctions) over a 4-month period

Number_Analysed.evidence: Group 1 (n=17, one suction) or Group 2 (n=17, two suctions)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Post-filtration, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), squames cells, and heparin were significantly reduced (P<0.001) in both groups

Funding.evidence: Supported by an educational grant from Pall Medical
